Title: Response by Minister Gan Kim Yong to the motion 'Towards a Low-Carbon Society'
Questions: What is the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the Energy Market Authority (EMA) doing?
answers: They are accelerating solar deployment and plan to import up to four gigawatts (GW) of electricity by 2035.

Title: Response by Minister Gan Kim Yong to the motion 'Towards a Low-Carbon Society'
Questions: Is there any subsidy for solar deployment?
answers: No, there are no subsidies for solar deployment as solar is already cheaper than retail electricity.

Title: Response by Minister Gan Kim Yong to the motion 'Towards a Low-Carbon Society'
Questions: What schemes does EMA have?
answers: EMA has schemes to facilitate the sale of excess electricity to the grid.

Title: Response by Minister Gan Kim Yong to the motion 'Towards a Low-Carbon Society'
Questions: What is the target year for importing up to four gigawatts (GW) of electricity?
answers: The target year is 2035.

Questions: Why is there no subsidy for solar deployment?
answers: Solar is already cheaper than retail electricity.

answers: They are accelerating solar deployment and planning to import up to four gigawatts (GW) of electricity by 2035.

Title: Response by Minister Gan Kim Yong to the motion 'Towards a Low-Carbon Society'
Questions: What is the purpose of EMA's schemes?
answers: EMA's schemes facilitate the sale of excess electricity to the grid.

Title: Response by Minister Gan Kim Yong to the motion 'Towards a Low-Carbon Society'
Questions: What is the capacity of electricity that is planned to be imported by 2035?
answers: Up to four gigawatts (GW) of electricity is planned to be imported by 2035.

Title: Response by Minister Gan Kim Yong to the motion 'Towards a Low-Carbon Society'
Questions: Is solar deployment encouraged in Singapore?
answers: Yes, solar deployment is being accelerated in Singapore.

Questions: What is the focus of the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the Energy Market Authority (EMA)?
answers: Their focus is on accelerating solar deployment and importing up to four gigawatts (GW) of electricity by 2035.
